Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I stood in the crowded school gym, clutching my voting slip, my eyes darting between the lines. The election official’s voice rang out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name fit the bill, but the new line was barely moving, while the original one inched forward steadily. I hesitated, feeling the weight of the official’s expectation to follow instructions as a responsible voter.

At the same time, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from my spouse: “Rough day. Can’t wait to talk.” I remembered our promise to communicate openly, especially when one of us seemed off. I wanted to be there, to listen and share, to be the partner they needed. But if I left the line now, I’d have to start over, and if I stayed, I’d be late getting home.

My heart pounded as I stood between the two lines, torn between being the attentive spouse I promised to be and the conscientious voter I believed I should be. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I felt paralyzed, unable to move.
